facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 739 NCE of 1974 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 739  NCE  of 1974.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 4th February 1974 of Punjab and Haryana High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 4th February 1974 of the Punjab and Harvana High Court in Civil Misc. Petn. No. 158-E of 1973 in Election Petn. No. 45 of 1972.

facts.text: Election held on March 11, 1972 for Haryana Vidhan Sabha from Jhajjar Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: In the election held on March 11, 1972 the appellant Shri Manphul Singh was elected to the Haryana Vidhan Sabha from the Jhajjar Constituency defeating his only rival, Shri Surinder Singh, the respondent before us, by a margin of 265 votes.

facts.text: Manphul Singh elected defeating Surinder Singh by 265 votes.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant Shri Manphul Singh was elected to the Haryana Vidhan Sabha from the Jhajjar Constituency defeating his only rival, Shri Surinder Singh, the respondent before us, by a margin of 265 votes.

facts.text: Surinder Singh filed election petition No. 45 of 1972 challenging Manphul Singh's election.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Surinder Singh, referred to hereinafter as the petitioner, filed an election petition challenging the election of the returned candidate on various allegations of which the following are material for the present purpose

facts.text: Petitioner alleged 28 votes cast by impersonators of dead voters in favour of returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: 1  28 votes were cast in favour of the returned candidate by some persons impersonating voters who were dead.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged 710 absentee voters impersonated in favour of returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: 2  710 absentee voters were impersonated by persons who polled their votes in favour of the returned candidate.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged 158 government servants impersonated as absent from villages.

anchor.surface_text: 3  158 government servants who were registered as voters in the Constituency but were number present in their respective villages and did number cast their votes, were impersonated and their votes were polled in favour of the returned candidate.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged 149 persons double voted in favour of returned candidate.

anchor.surface_text: 4  149 persons, registered as voters at two or more different places in the companystituency, polled their votes twice or more than twice in favour of the returned candidate.

facts.text: Petitioner filed application on December 1, 1972 for production of counterfoils.

anchor.surface_text: In an application filed on December 1, 1972 the petitioner suggested a procedure to enable him to prove his case of impersonation and double voting. It was stated that he would produce genuine voters who should be shown the companynterfoils of the ballot papers to test whether the companynterfoils carried their genuine signatures and for this purpose the petitioner asked for production of the companynterfoils.

facts.text: High Court order dated January 5, 1973 allowed inspection of two counterfoils.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer was opposed on behalf of the returned candidate but the High Court by its order dated January 5, 1973 allowed inspection of two companynterfoils of ballot papers to companyfirm the oral evidence of the witness that he had impersonated two voters by signing their names in the companynterfoils.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed earlier appeal from High Court interlocutory order, reported in AIR 1973 S.C. 2158.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that from an earlier interlocutory order passed in this election dispute, the returned candidate had preferred an appeal to this Court which was dismissed. In the Judgment in that case, reported in AIR 1973 S.C. 2158  Manphul Singh v. Surinder Singh ,

facts.text: On December 17, 1973 High Court allowed two fingerprint experts to compare thumb impressions on counterfoils.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1973 the High Court allowed the prayer made on behalf of the petitioner to allow two finger-print experts named by the petitioner to companypare the thumb impressions of some of the witnesses with the thumb impressions on the relevant companynterfoils.

facts.text: Returned candidate filed Civil Misc. Application No. 158-E/73 on December 18, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On December 18, 1973 the returned candidate made an application, registered as Civil Miscellaneous Application No. 158-E/73, on which the order under appeal was passed on February 4, 1974.

facts.text: High Court on February 4, 1974 found prima facie impersonation in 310 cases and allowed inspection of counterfoils for those.

anchor.surface_text: Having examined the evidence of the witnesses recorded till then, the High Court found prima facie that there had been impersonation in about 310 cases and allowed the petitioners experts to inspect the companynterfoils of the ballot papers pertaining to these 310 voters.

facts.text: High Court List A: 5 dead voters prima facie impersonated.

anchor.surface_text: List A companytains particulars of dead voters who are alleged to have been impersonated. They are 5 in number.

facts.text: High Court List B: 126 voters prima facie impersonated based on own testimony.

anchor.surface_text: List B includes the particulars of voters examined on oath and found prima facie to have been impersonated on the basis of their own testimony. The number of such voters is 126.

facts.text: High Court List G: 63 cases of multiple voting, 17 twice in constituency, 46 once here and another.

anchor.surface_text: List G companytains particulars of multiple voting. This list includes two categories  a  those who polled twice in the companystituency, and  b  those who polled once in the companystituency and again in another companystituency.Category  a  companytains 17 and category  b  companytains 46 such cases.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above this appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: High Court accepted that for 63 multiple voters, votes polled at both places as common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground between the parties that the votes of such voters have been polled at both the places. In respect of these 63 persons therefore the petitioner must be held to have adduced prima facie evidence in support of his allegations.

issues.text: Whether inspection of counterfoils should be allowed absent a prima facie case of impersonation

anchor.surface_text: the returned candidate contended that the counterfoils were secret documents and their inspection should not be allowed unless a prima facie case

issues.text: Whether the High Court's order allowing inspection of counterfoils amounted to a fishing or roving enquiry

anchor.surface_text: amounted to a fishing enquiry not permissible in law the prayer made in the application was for revoking the permission granted to the finger-print

issues.text: Whether the High Court failed to consider the quality of evidence and relied merely on its volume to find a prima facie case

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg appearing for the appellant made a grievance that the High Court did number apply its mind to judge the quality of the evidence in order to find out whether really there was a prima facie case and depended on the volume of the evidence adduced in making the impugned order.

issues.text: Whether there was prima facie material to support the allegation of multiple voting

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg also companytended that there was numbermaterial to support the allegation of multiple voting. This is what the learned Judge of the High Court says on this aspect of the case I have been taken through various parts of the electoral roll by learned companynsel for the petitioner who companytends that each one of such persons is shown to be registered at two places in the companystituency or in different companystituencies by reason of the fact that his or her description as well as the description of his or her family members or some of them given in the two places is the same

issues.text: Whether the High Court applied the correct legal principles regarding secrecy of ballot, prima facie case, and inspection in election petitions

anchor.surface_text: We do number propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter indeed, to attempt to lay down such a rule would be inexpedient and unreasonable. The principle stated. in Dr. Jagjit Singhs case  Supra  was reaffirmed by this Court in Sashi Bhusan v. Prof. Balraj Madhok and Ors, 1972 2 S.C.R. 177.

arguments.claim: Inspection of ballot papers or counterfoils requires material facts enabling consideration in interest of justice; secrecy important; no roving or fishing enquiry

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as regards inspection of ballot papers or their counterfoils seems to be well established. In Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh, AIR 1966 S.C. 773, this Court observed

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter indeed, to attempt to lay down such a rule would be inexpedient and unreasonable. The principle stated

arguments.court_reasoning: Procedure reasonable upon prima facie proof; earlier appeal dismissed

holdings.text: Inspection of counterfoils of ballot papers should not be allowed unless a prima facie case in support of the allegation of impersonation is made out

anchor.surface_text: In disposing of the application the High Court also proceeded on the footing that the person seeking inspection of the counterfoils must prove a prima facie case in support of his allegation before the counterfoils can be made available to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court required and found prima facie case; Supreme Court upholds following precedents like Dr. Jagjit Singh requiring material facts before inspection

holdings.text: The High Court's order allowing inspection did not amount to a fishing or roving enquiry

anchor.surface_text: Having examined the evidence of the witnesses recorded till then, the High Court found prima facie that there had been impersonation in about 310 cases and allowed the petitioners experts to inspect the counterfoils of the ballot papers pertaining to these 310 voters. The High Court tabulated the result of the examination of the evidence of the witnesses in seven lists

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inspection limited to specific 310 cases classified into Lists A-G based on witness evidence and particulars, not general roving enquiry; principles from precedents applied

holdings.text: The High Court applied its mind to the quality of evidence and did not merely rely on volume to find prima facie case

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the criticism is justified. The High Court classified the various types of impersonation alleged into seven categories mentioning all relevant particulars including the names of witnesses on whose evi- dence the allegation in each category was based.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court categorized evidence into seven lists with particulars and witnesses; satisfied unrebutted evidence sufficient for prima facie impersonation; not arbitrary

holdings.text: Prima facie evidence adduced in support of allegation of multiple voting in respect of 63 persons

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground between the parties that the votes of such voters have been polled at both the places. In respect of these 63 persons therefore the petitioner must be held to have adduced prima facie evidence in support of his allegations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Electoral rolls show same voter descriptions at multiple places; common ground that votes polled at both; High Court finding upheld

holdings.text: No hard and fast rule can be laid down for ordering inspection of ballot papers or counterfoils; decision depends on facts of each case

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter indeed, to attempt to lay down such a rule would be inexpedient and unreasonable. The principle stated in Dr. Jagjit Singhs case Supra was reaffirmed by this Court in Sashi Bhusan v. Prof. Balraj Madhok and Ors

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirming precedents; rigid test inexpedient; case-to-case basis considering justice, secrecy, and material facts

holdings.text: Prayer for inspection must be supported by material facts, specific allegations, and be bona fide

anchor.surface_text: The allegations in support of a prayer for inspection must not be vague or indefinite they must be supported by material facts and prayer made must be a bona fide one. If these conditions are satisfied, the Court will be justified in permitting inspection of ballot papers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From Sashi Bhusan precedent; High Court satisfied conditions through witness evidence and lists

holdings.text: The appeal against the High Court's order allowing inspection is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above this appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie case established; High Court applied correct principles; criticisms rejected

precedents.citation: AIR 1973 S.C. 2158  Manphul Singh v. Surinder Singh

anchor.surface_text: AIR 1973 S.C. 2158  Manphul Singh v. Surinder Singh

precedents.cited_proposition: Prima facie proof is required before inspection of counterfoils, and the procedure of producing genuine voters to check signatures on counterfoils is reasonable and clear.
precedents.cited_holding: Nothing could be clearer or more reasonable than this. Obviously, in this context proving meant proving prima facie, or there would not have any necessity of examining the counter-foils.

precedents.citation: Dr. Jagjit Singh v., Giani Kartar Singh,  AIR 1966 S.C. 773

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Jagjit Singh v., Giani Kartar Singh,  AIR 1966 S.C. 773

precedents.case_name: Dr. Jagjit Singh v. Giani Kartar Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Application for inspection of ballot papers must specify material facts to satisfy tribunal that inspection serves justice, while safeguarding ballot secrecy and preventing fishing or roving enquiries; no hard and fast rule can be laid down.
precedents.cited_holding: An application made for the inspection of ballot boxes must give material facts which would enable the Tribunal to consider whether in the interest of justice, the ballot boxes should be inspected or not. In dealing with this question, the importance of the secrecy of the ballot papers cannot be ignored ... election petitioners do not get a chance to make a roving or fishing enquiry ... We do not propose to lay down any hard and fast rule in this matter.

precedents.citation: Sashi Bhusan v. Prof. Balraj Madhok and Ors, 1972 2 S.C.R. 177

anchor.surface_text: Sashi Bhusan v. Prof. Balraj Madhok and Ors, 1972 2 S.C.R. 177

precedents.case_name: Sashi Bhusan v. Prof. Balraj Madhok and Ors
precedents.cited_proposition: No rigid test for ordering inspection of ballot papers as facts differ; secrecy important but justice paramount; allegations must not be vague, must be supported by material facts and be bona fide.
precedents.cited_holding: Facts naturally differ from case to case. Therefore it is dangerous to lay down any rigid test in the matter of ordering an inspection. It is no doubt true that a Judge while deciding the question of inspection of the ballot papers must bear in mind the importance of the secrecy of the ballot papers. The allegations in support of a prayer for inspection must not be vague or indefinite they must be supported by material facts and prayer made must be a bona fide one.
